choices.text: Nervous tissue is more susceptible to the complications of oxygen toxicity
The reactive oxygen species oxidize the PUFA of cell membrane as well as cellular enzyme, thus damaging severely the cellular metabolic system.
At 4 atmospheric pressure, the amount of O2 dissolved is markedly increased to 9ml/100ml nearly

questions.text: A 48-year-old deep-sea diver descends rapidly to a depth of around 100 feet under the sea. There are chances of acute oxygen toxicity. Which of the following is true about it?
questions.solution:
Explanation

  • Option A: Nervous tissue is especially vulnerable due to its high lipid (myelin) content, making it highly sensitive to oxidative damage. Symptoms include visual disturbances, dizziness, nausea, muscle twitching, and seizures (Paul Bert effect).
  • Option B: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) such as superoxide anions, hydroxyl radicals, and hydrogen peroxide are generated at high oxygen pressures. These ROS:
  • Oxidize polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) in cell membranes, damaging membrane integrity.
  • Inactivate vital enzymes, disrupting cellular metabolism.
  • Induce DNA damage and apoptosis when severe.
  • Option C: At a pressure of 4 atmospheres (about 100 feet underwater), the amount of dissolved oxygen in blood increases significantly, from around 2 ml/100 ml at 1 atm to nearly 9 ml/100 ml, contributing to toxicity risk.

Key Takeaway:

  • At high tissue oxygen levels (high pO2), molecular oxygen is converted into reactive oxygen species like superoxide anions. These ROS cause oxidative damage to cellular membranes and enzymes.
  • The nervous system, due to its high lipid content, is particularly vulnerable to the complications of acute oxygen toxicity.

questions.text: There are various sites in the body where we can measure body temperature. Among the following, which gives accurate results?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The rectal temperature is the most accurate measurement site for body temperature, as it gives exact values to core body temperature due to proximity, and it varies least with the atmospheric temperature. Due to patient discomfort, it is usually not performed.
  • Oral temperaturemeasurement is commonly done as it is easier and very convenient for the patient and doctor. The oral temperature is normally 5°C lower than the rectal temperature. It is affected by many factors (ingestion of hot or cold fluids, gum chewing, smoking, and mouth breathing). (Option A ruled out)
  • Axillary temperaturemeasurement is done when oral temperature cannot be measured, as in children and mandibular fractures. It also varies with environmental factors. (Option B ruled out)
  • Skin temperatureis a rough method to identify if the patient has a fever or not. It is done by palpating with the back of the hand to the forehead of the (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

  • The rectal temperature is the most accurate measurement site for body temperature, as it gives exact values to core body temperature due to proximity, and it varies least with the atmospheric temperature.

questions.text: A patient’s body temperature is assessed. Which factor does not contribute to body heat production?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Urination is a mechanical excretory process and does not significantly contribute to thermogenesis.

  • Basal metabolism is the primary mechanism for generating body Factors that increase the metabolism increase the body temperature via increased heat production.
  • There are many factors involved in heat production, as
    • Muscular activity (increased metabolism) (Option D ruled out)
    • Hormonal levels (thyroid increases metabolism, so does temperature) (Option C ruled out)
    • Food intake (Specific dynamic action of food) (Option A ruled out)
  • Heat loss mechanisms from the body are
    • Radiation, conduction, convection
    • Evaporation
    • Urination, Defecation
    • Respiration

Key Takeaway:

Major heat loss mechanisms are radiation, convection, conduction, and evaporation; urination and defecation are minor.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male who lives in a coastal region where the temperature usually remains near 30°C throughout the year travels to a much colder area, where temperatures consistently stay below 0°C. Which of the following mechanisms will be activated in his body to regulate temperature?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

In response to exposure to a much colder environment, the body initiates shivering, an involuntary mechanism involving rapid, rhythmic muscle contractions that generate heat to maintain core body temperature.

Physiological Responses to Cold & Heat:

Key Takeaway:

Shivering increases heat production in cold environments, unlike vasodilation, increased respiration, or anorexia, which do not conserve heat.

questions.text: Which of the following organs does not utilise a countercurrent exchange mechanism for thermoregulation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The rectum does not engage in countercurrent exchange. Its function is related to faecal storage and expulsion, and while it has a rich blood supply, it does not support a countercurrent mechanism for heat or solute exchange.

  • A countercurrent exchanger involves two closely associated tubes (or flows) moving in opposite directions, allowing efficient exchange of heat, gases, or solutes, minimising loss and maintaining a gradient
  • Seen in:
    • Skin: Arteriovenous anastomoses and blood vessels in the skin can exhibit countercurrent heat exchange to reduce heat loss in cold environments. (Option A)
    • Scrotum: The pampiniform plexus functions as a countercurrent heat exchanger, cooling arterial blood before it reaches the testes to maintain optimal temperature for spermatogenesis. (Option C)
    • Kidney: The vasa recta in the juxtamedullary nephrons maintain the medullary osmotic gradient through countercurrent exchange of solutes and water, essential for urine concentration. (Option D)

choices.text: It inhibits the growth of causative microorganism
It slows down the growth of some tumors

questions.text: A patient with a fever is assessed. How does fever contribute to homeostasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fever is a protective physiological response triggered by the hypothalamus in response to pyrogens released during infections or tissue damage.
  • It plays a significant role in maintaining homeostasis by enhancing the body’s defence mechanisms.
  • Fever as a Protective Physiological Response:
    • Inhibits Growth of Microorganisms: (Option A)
      • Most pathogens (bacteria, viruses, fungi) thrive within a narrow temperature range.
      • Elevated body temperature disrupts this range, slowing or halting their replication.
    • Increases Antibody Production: (Option B)
      • Higher temperatures boost the immune system's efficiency.
      • This includes enhanced T-cell activation and increased antibody synthesis, leading to a more effective immune response.
    • Slows the Growth of Tumours: (Option C)
      • Mild hyperthermia can inhibit the growth of certain tumour cells.
      • It is sometimes used in conjunction with cancer treatments (hyperthermia therapy).

choices.text: A) Use of a breathing mixture containing helium and a low concentration of oxygen
Very slow ascent taking around more than 2 hours

questions.text: Mr. Tom, an experienced deep-sea diver, presented to the emergency department with severe joint pain and limb weakness. Before the incident, he had been diving at a depth of 100 feet for an hour and then ascended rapidly within 20 minutes. How could this condition have been prevented?
questions.solution:
Explanation

Mr. Tom's symptoms are classic signs of decompression sickness (also known as "the bends"), which occurs when inert gases (mainly nitrogen) that have dissolved in body tissues under high pressure form bubbles during rapid ascent and depressurisation.

Decompression Sickness

Cause:

  • Caused by bubbles of nitrogen gas forming in the blood and tissues.
  • This happens when a person is exposed to rapid decompression (fast ascent to lower pressure).
  • Mechanism:
    • At high pressure (underwater or in a pressurised environment), nitrogen dissolves in body tissues.
    • Rapid reduction in pressure (surfacing too quickly) causes nitrogen to come out of solution and form bubbles.

Common Situations:

  • Scuba diving (most common)
  • Unpressurised aircraft at high altitudes

Symptoms:

  • Fatigue
  • Headache
  • Vertigo/dizziness
  • Skin rash ('cutis marmorata')
  • Joint and muscle pain ('the bends')
  • Neurological symptoms: confusion, paralysis, seizures (severe cases)
  • Cardiopulmonary symptoms: chest pain, shortness of breath ('the chokes') in severe cases

Treatment:

  • Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy
    • The patient is placed in a recompression chamber.
    • Pressure is increased to dissolve nitrogen bubbles again.
    • Then pressure is slowly decreased to allow safe elimination of nitrogen through breathing.

This condition could have been prevented by the following:

  • Use of a breathing mixture containing helium and a low concentration of oxygen (Option A):
    • Helium is used to replace nitrogen in the breathing mixture because it is less soluble, diffuses faster, and has much lower narcotic effects (only about one-fifth that of nitrogen).
    • A lower oxygen concentration helps prevent oxygen toxicity, especially under high pressure.
  • Tank decompression (Recompression Therapy) (Option B):
    • If a diver ascends too quickly and shows symptoms, immediate placement in a pressurised decompression chamber (hyperbaric chamber) is critical.
    • The diver is first recompressed to dissolve the nitrogen bubbles, and then the pressure is slowly decreased, allowing controlled elimination of nitrogen from the body.
  • Very slow ascent with staged decompression (Option C):
    • A slow, stepwise ascent over more than two hours, with stops at regular intervals, allows nitrogen to be released gradually through respiration.
    • This technique ensures that only small amounts of nitrogen bubbles form at any given time, preventing their accumulation and associated symptoms.

Key takeaway:

Decompression sickness is prevented by using helium-oxygen mixtures, tank decompression, and slow ascent to minimise nitrogen bubble formation.

questions.text: The arrows in the following image show heat loss from the body via different mechanisms. Heat loss is vital for maintaining body temperature. Identify the mechanism of heat loss indicated by the question mark.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Convection involves heat loss through the movement of air or fluid over the skin. In the image, the arrows represent warm air rising from the skin and being replaced by cooler air, illustrating this mechanism.

Heat Loss Mechanisms:

  • Conduction: (Option A ruled out)
    • Heat transfer through direct contact with a cooler object (e.g., sitting on a cold metal bench).
    • Minimal contributor to overall heat loss.
  • Convection:
    • Heat is carried away by moving air or fluid (e.g., wind or water currents).
    • Warm air near the skin is displaced by cooler air, which absorbs more body heat.
    • This is the process shown in the image, where moving air currents are removing heat from the skin.
  • Radiation: (Option C ruled out)
    • Heat is emitted as infrared rays from the skin to the cooler surrounding environment, without direct contact.
  • Evaporation: (Option D ruled out)
    • Occurs via sweat evaporating from the skin.
    • This is the only mechanism that can result in heat loss even when the surrounding temperature is higher than the body temperature.

questions.text: The following is a list of problems that are related to underwater diving. Out of all, which among the following is a problem of rapid ascent under the sea?
questions.solution:
Explanation

Among the listed conditions, Dysbarism is the one directly related to rapid ascent from underwater.

Dysbarism (Caisson's disease or Decompression sickness):

  • This occurs during rapid ascent, when dissolved inert gases (mainly nitrogen) come out of solution too quickly, forming bubbles in the blood and tissues.
  • These bubbles can block vessels, irritate tissues, and lead to joint pain, limb weakness, dizziness, and other symptoms.
  • It is the defining condition caused by a rapid reduction in pressure.

Explanation of other options:

Oxygen Toxicity (Option A): Occurs during descent at high pressure, where increased pO��� leads to excessive dissolved oxygen. This causes free radical formation, leading to oxidative damage, especially in the nervous system. It is a complication of breathing high concentrations of oxygen under pressure, not of ascent.

Nitrogen Narcosis (Option B): Also occurs during descent, particularly at depths beyond 100 feet. At high pressure, the partial pressure of nitrogen (pN2) increases, and nitrogen dissolves in lipid-rich neuronal membranes, causing narcotic effects (e.g., euphoria, impaired judgment). Again, this is a problem of deep diving, not ascent.

Key takeaway:

Dysbarism (decompression sickness) results from rapid ascent, causing nitrogen bubbles to form in tissues and blood, unlike oxygen toxicity or nitrogen narcosis, which occur during descent.

questions.text: A runner hyperventilates 30 minutes post-race. What drives this prolonged ventilation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Even after exercise has ended, ventilation remains elevated for some time (can be up to 90 minutes). This is primarily due to the body's effort to clear lactic acid accumulated during anaerobic metabolism.

  • Lactic acid produced during anaerobic exercise leads to acidemia, increasing the H⁺ concentration.
  • This metabolic acidosis triggers chemoreceptor-mediated hyperventilation even after exercise ends.
  • This is part of the respiratory compensation to normalise pH.

Explanation of other options:

Increase in arterial PCO₂ (Option A): During and after exercise, arterial PCO₂ is typically normal or even reduced due to increased ventilation. It does not stimulate post-exercise ventilation.

A fall in arterial PO₂ (Option B): Arterial PO₂ is usually normal or slightly elevated post-exercise because of enhanced alveolar ventilation. There’s no hypoxia to drive increased ventilation.

Key Takeaway:

Post-exercise hyperventilation is driven primarily by elevated arterial H⁺ concentration from lactic acidosis.

questions.text: Decompression sickness is a disorder commonly seen in caisson workers and deep-sea divers. What is the most common symptom of decompression sickness?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In 85% to 90% of cases of decompression sickness, the primary symptom is pain in the joints and muscles, particularly in the arms and legs.
  • This intense joint pain is referred to as the bends, a term commonly used to describe decompression sickness itself.
  • The condition occurs when nitrogen that has dissolved in body tissues under high pressure forms bubbles during rapid ascent. These bubbles can accumulate in joints, causing severe pain, especially during movement.
  • Other possible symptoms include:
    • Neurological symptoms (in about 5% to 10% of cases):
      • Dizziness (Option C ruled out)
      • Paralysis (Option B ruled out)
      • Collapse
      • Unconsciousness
    • Cardiopulmonary involvement (rare):
      • Coronary ischemia, when nitrogen bubbles lodge in the coronary arteries (Option D ruled out)
      • "The chokes": Severe shortness of breath due to microbubbles blocking pulmonary capillaries, which may lead to pulmonary oedema or death in extreme cases
    • Cutaneous and sensory symptoms:
      • Numbness
      • Tingling
      • Itching sensation

Key takeaway:

Bends (joint pain) is the most common and defining symptom of decompression sickness, making it the hallmark feature.

choices.text: To remove buildup of lactic acid in the muscles
To replace the store oxygen which is used during exercise

questions.text: The body normally contains about 2 liters of stored oxygen that can be used for aerobic metabolism even without breathing any new oxygen. In addition, about 9 liters more oxygen must be consumed to reconstitute the phosphagen system and the lactic acid system. After heavy exercise the amount of oxygen that is required to replenish the store oxygen is called oxygen debt. What is the primary cause of oxygen debt in the later portion of recovery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • During heavy exercise, the body rapidly consumes its available stored oxygen (about 2 litres), which is used for aerobic metabolism. Additionally, the phosphagen system (ATP and creatine phosphate) and the anaerobic glycolytic system are engaged to meet the high energy demand.
  • Once the exercise stops, the body continues to consume oxygen at an elevated rate, even during rest. This excess oxygen consumption post-exercise is known as oxygen debt and serves several purposes:
    • Early phase of recovery:
      • Replenishment of the phosphagen system (ATP and creatine phosphate)
      • Replacement of oxygen stores in haemoglobin and myoglobin
    • Later phase of recovery:
      • Removal of accumulated lactic acid from the muscles, either by:
        • Conversion back to pyruvate for use in aerobic metabolism
        • Conversion to glucose via gluconeogenesis in the liver
      • This lactic acid clearance is the primary contributor to oxygen debt in the later phase of recovery, accounting for a large portion of the total 5 litres of oxygen repaid after intense exercise.

Explanation of other options:

To replenish the phosphagen system (Option A): Occurs early in the recovery period. The phosphagen system (ATP and creatine phosphate) is restored quickly in the first few minutes after exercise. While it contributes to oxygen debt, it does not account for the later portion, which is dominated by lactic acid clearance.

Excessive carbon dioxide removal (Option B): This is not a primary contributor to oxygen debt. While CO₂ levels rise during exercise and some increased ventilation may help remove it, carbon dioxide is eliminated rapidly after exercise and does not require prolonged oxygen consumption like lactate removal does.

To replace the stored oxygen used during exercise (Option D): This refers to the oxygen bound to haemoglobin, myoglobin, and dissolved in body fluids. Replenishing these oxygen reserves occurs early, within the first few minutes of recovery. Like option A, this is a minor, early contributor to total oxygen debt, not the main cause of the prolonged oxygen requirement.

questions.text: A 41-year-old male presented to the doctorA 41-year-old male presented with involuntary muscle contractions and cramps. He was found to have tetany and an acid-base imbalance. What is the probable acid-base disorder? with involuntary muscle contractions and muscle cramps. On evaluation the patient is found to have tetany. Doctor also observed that the patient has acid base imbalance. Probable acid base imbalance is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tetany is a clinical sign of increased neuromuscular excitability, most commonly due to hypocalcemia, particularly low ionised (free) calcium, not total calcium
  • In metabolic alkalosis, the pH of the blood is elevated, which increases calcium binding to albumin. This reduces the concentration of free ionised calcium in the blood, even when total calcium may be normal, leading to tetany, muscle cramps, and carpopedal spasms.

Explanation of other options:

Metabolic Acidosis (Option B): Acidosis increases the ionised calcium level (by competing with calcium for albumin binding sites), so symptoms of tetany are less likely. Hence, metabolic acidosis does not cause tetany.

Respiratory Acidosis (Option C): Respiratory acidosis occurs due to CO₂ retention, usually from hypoventilation. It does not significantly decrease ionised calcium, so tetany is uncommon.

Key Takeaway:

  • In alkalosis, an increase in alkalinity in the body will bind to the calcium ion and cause a fall in ionised calcium level, producing the symptoms of

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was evaluated by a sports physiologist to assess which sport would suit him best. Muscle fibre analysis revealed that he has more than 70% slow-twitch muscle fibres. Based on this, which of the following competitive sports is he most likely to perform better in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Human skeletal muscles consist of a mix of fast-twitch (Type II) and slow-twitch (Type I) muscle fibres.
  • Slow-twitch fibres are more efficient at using oxygen to generate energy (ATP) for sustained, continuous muscle contractions over long periods.
  • These fibres are best suited for endurance activities like long-distance swimming, running, and
  • Having more than 70% slow-twitch fibres strongly favours endurance sports.
  • Slow-twitch fibres (Type I) are rich in mitochondria, ideal for aerobic, endurance activities like

Explanation of other options:

Weightlifting (Option B): Relies primarily on fast-twitch fibres, which are suited for short bursts of strength and power. Not ideal for someone with predominantly slow-twitch fibres.

Sprinting (Option C): Requires explosive speed and quick contractions, which are provided by fast-twitch fibres. Athletes with a high percentage of slow-twitch fibres would likely be at a disadvantage.

High jump (Option D): Another event that requires short, explosive bursts of power, relying on fast-twitch fibres for maximal force generation in a short time.

Key takeaway:

  • Slow-twitch muscle fibres are best for endurance-based activities.

Swimming is an endurance sport, making it the most suitable choice for an individual with >70% slow-twitch fibres.

choices.text: Resting cardiac output increases due to training
Maximal Cardiac output can be increased during exercise due to training
Resting heart rate becomes less than 60/min

questions.text: Which of the following is not a benefit of regular exercise training?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • At rest, cardiac output remains unchanged despite physiological adaptations.
  • This is because stroke volume increases, but resting heart rate decreases, keeping the product (CO = SV × HR) approximately the same.
  • The body's oxygen demand at rest doesn't change, so there's no need for an increased cardiac output.

Regular aerobic exercise induces several beneficial cardiovascular adaptations, including:

  • Hypertrophy of cardiac muscle, especially of the left ventricle, which enlarges the heart chambers and increases stroke volume. (Option D)
  • Resting heart rate decreases (often below 60/min in athletes, termed athletic bradycardia) due to increased parasympathetic tone and more efficient heart function. (Option C)
  • Maximal cardiac output during exercise increases because both maximum stroke volume and, to some extent, maximum heart rate are enhanced through training. (Option B)

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman is being evaluated for a disorder related to pH imbalance. An anion gap is advised. Which ion contributes to an increased anion gap?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An increased anion gap occurs due to unmeasured anions like lactate in metabolic acidosis.

Anion Gap:

  • The anion gap is the difference between measured cation and anion concentrations in the blood.
  • Formula: Anion gap = (Na+ + K+) - (Cl- + HCO3-)
    • Normal: ~12 mEq/L
    • Range: 8 to 16 mEq/L
    • Note: Potassium is sometimes omitted due to its low and constant concentration. (Option D)
  • Clinical Relevance:
    • Increased Anion Gap: Due to an increase in unmeasured anions (UA) or a decrease in unmeasured cations (UC).
    • Decreased Anion Gap: Due to an increase in UC or a decrease in UA.
  • Causes of increased anion gap:
    • Increase in UA
    • Increase in serum lactate, ketoacids, and uremia (Option A)
    • Certain medications: carbenicillin, penicillin
    • Dehydration: concentrated normal anions
    • Alkalemia
    • Decrease in UC concentrations: Ca2+, Mg2+
    • Increase in serum albumin
    • Toxins: ethylene glycol, methanol, salicylate, paraldehyde
  • Causes of decreased anion gap:
    • Increase in normal cations, especially Ca2+, Mg2+, and globulins (Option B)
    • Retention of abnormal cations (e.g., multiple myeloma)
    • Loss of UA: Hypoalbuminemia (Option C)

questions.text: A fitness trainer assesses a client's exercise intensity. What is the Metabolic Equivalent of Task (MET) range that defines heavy exercise?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • MET (Metabolic Equivalent of Task) is a standard unit used to estimate the amount of oxygen consumed and energy expended during physical activities.
  • 1 MET is defined as the resting oxygen consumption, which is approximately:
    • 250 ml/min for an average adult male
    • 200 ml/min for an average adult female
  • Based on MET values, physical activity intensity is categorised as:

These classifications are based on parameters like oxygen consumption, heart rate, and relative workload.

questions.text: The graph below shows the relationship between ventilation and varying alveolar PO2 levels, with alveolar PCO2 held constant. Based on the curve marked by the arrow, what can be inferred about the level of alveolar PCO2(PACO2)?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Normally, When alveolar PCO2 is normal (≈40 mmHg), ventilation stays almost flat as long as alveolar PO2 is above 60 mmHg. Ventilation only increases steeply when PO2 falls below 60 mmHg.
  • In this graph, ventilation is already high even when PO2 is normal (around 90-110 mmHg).
  • This pattern can only happen if CO2 is high, because:
  • High CO 2(hypercapnia) directly stimulates the respiratory center, causing more ventilation even when oxygen is normal.
  • When PCO2 is >44 mmHg, the drive from CO₂ overrides the usual flat response to oxygen.
  • If PCO2 were normal or low, the curve would remain flat at normal PO2 and would only rise sharply after PO2 drops below 60 mmHg.


Key Takeaway:

Ventilation increases significantly when alveolar PCO2 exceeds 44 mmHg, even if PO2 remains near normal, due to the dominant stimulatory effect of CO2 on respiration.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female athlete presents with several physical disturbances. On evaluation, she is found to have leptin deficiency. Which of the following symptoms is likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation

Leptin is a hormone primarily secreted by adipose (fat) tissue, and it plays a crucial role in energy balance, reproductive health, and bone metabolism.

In young female athletes with very low body fat, leptin levels may drop significantly, leading to:

  • Menstrual disturbances: Leptin is involved in regulating the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Its deficiency can suppress GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) secretion, leading to amenorrhea or irregular cycles. (Option A)
  • Delayed puberty: A critical level of body fat and leptin is necessary to trigger pubertal onset. Low leptin levels may delay this process. (Option B)
  • Bone mineral loss: Leptin deficiency can impair estrogen production, which in turn reduces bone mineral density, increasing the risk of osteopenia or osteoporosis, especially in young athletes. (Option C)

This clinical picture is often referred to as part of the Female Athlete Triad, which includes:

  1. Low energy availability (with or without disordered eating)
  2. Menstrual dysfunction
  3. Low bone mineral density

Key takeaway:

  • Leptin, secreted by fat cells, is essential for normal reproductive and skeletal development.
  • Its deficiency in athletes with low body fat can lead to menstrual disturbances, delayed puberty, and bone mineral loss.

questions.text: The following is the data of a patient suffering from an acid-base disorder: pH is 7.25, HCO3- is 18.1 mEq/L, PCO3 is 34 mmHg. Identify the disorder.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Since pH is low, the patient has
  • The primary disturbance is low bicarbonate, indicating metabolic acidosis.
  • The low PCO2 reflects compensatory respiratory alkalosis (hyperventilation to blow off CO2 and counter the acidosis).

Explanation of other options:

Respiratory acidosis (Option A) would show high PCO2 and often high/normal HCO3 -.

Respiratory alkalosis (Option C) would have high pH and low PCO2, but HCO2 would also be decreased over time.

Metabolic alkalosis (Option D) would show high pH and high HCO3 -.

questions.text: The following graph shows that after several weeks of a particular type of training (yellow line), the percentage increase in muscle strength is significantly greater than that seen with another type of training (black line). Which type of exercise is most effective in increasing skeletal muscle strength?
questions.solution:
Explanation

The graph shows the percentage increase in muscle strength over weeks, with the yellow line (resistive training) showing a greater increase than the black line (aerobic training). Weight lifting induces muscle hypertrophy by recruiting fast-twitch fibres, increasing strength more than aerobic exercises.

Exercise training is broadly categorised into two types:

  1. Resistive (Anaerobic) Training, e.g., Weight lifting
    • Involves exercises performed against resistance, which directly challenge and stimulate the skeletal muscles.
    • This leads to muscle hypertrophy, improved neuromuscular coordination, and increased muscle strength over time.
  2. No-load (Aerobic) Training, e.g., Running, Cycling, Yoga (Option B, C, & D)
    • These activities involve repetitive, low-resistance movements aimed at improving cardiovascular endurance and general fitness.
    • While they offer many health benefits, they are less effective in significantly increasing muscle strength compared to resistive exercises.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female was admitted to the emergency department. Investigations are done. As per the physician, the patient has respiratory alkalosis. What could be the probable cause in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Respiratory alkalosis occurs when there is excessive loss of CO2 due to hyperventilation, leading to:

  • ↓ PaCO2 (hypocapnia)
  • ↑ pH (alkalosis)

Key Takeaway:

High altitude hypoxia triggers hyperventilation to increase oxygen uptake, leading to reduced PCO2 and respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: A marathon runner before a race has to look for his diet before the few days of competition. Which among the following diet help the marathoner to get maximum endurance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Endurance performance, especially in long-distance events like marathons, depends heavily on the availability of glycogen in skeletal muscles.

  • A high-carbohydrate diet allows the muscles to store significantly more glycogen, which is the primary fuel used during prolonged aerobic exercise.
  • In contrast, high-fat and mixed diets result in much lower glycogen storage, reducing endurance capacity. (Option A & D)
  • The amount of glycogen stored per kg of muscle under different diets:
    • High carbohydrate diet: ~40 g/kg
    • Mixed diet: ~20 g/kg
    • High-fat diet: ~6 g/kg
  • As a result, the duration of sustained endurance exercise also differs significantly:
    • High carbohydrate diet: ~240 minutes
    • Mixed diet: ~120 minutes
    • High-fat diet: ~85 minutes

This illustrates why athletes, especially endurance runners, often follow carbohydrate-loading protocols before competition.

Explanation of other options:

High-protein diet (Option C): A high-protein diet does not improve endurance performance because:

  • Proteins are not stored as an immediate energy source; they are primarily used for tissue repair and enzyme/hormone synthesis.
  • During prolonged aerobic activity, the body primarily depends on muscle glycogen and fat oxidation for energy, with protein contributing only minimally (5-10% in extreme cases).
  • Excessive protein intake can even reduce carbohydrate intake, leading to lower glycogen stores and decreased endurance.

Key takeaway:

  • A person who consumes a high-carbohydrate diet stores far more glycogen in muscles than does a person who consumes either a mixed diet or a high-fat diet.
  • Therefore, endurance is enhanced by a high-carbohydrate diet.

questions.text: A patient with an acid-base imbalance is evaluated. Which is not a blood buffer system?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ammonia (NH3) is a renal buffer, not a blood buffer. It is important in urinary buffering by forming ammonium (NH4+) to trap H+ and excrete it.

  • A buffer system is a chemical system that resists changes in pH by binding or releasing hydrogen ions (H+). The major blood buffer systems are:
    • Carbonic acid-bicarbonate system → Primary extracellular buffer (Option D)
    • Haemoglobin buffer system → Important in buffering CO2 and H+ in RBCs (Option B)
    • Plasma proteins → Act as buffers due to their amino acid residues (mainly albumin) (Option A)

Key Takeaway:

  • Blood buffers: Bicarbonate, haemoglobin, plasma proteins

Renal buffers: Phosphate buffer, ammonia buffer

questions.text: A cyclist experiences increased leg muscle blood flow during a race. What is the primary cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • During exercise, although the sympathetic nervous system is globally activated to increase cardiac output (via increased heart rate and stroke volume), the primary factor responsible for the increase in local blood flow to exercising muscles is the accumulation of local metabolic by-products.
  • These metabolites include:
    • Lactic acid
    • Carbon dioxide (CO₂)
    • Potassium ions (K⁺)
    • Adenosine
    • Hydrogen ions (H⁺)
  • These substances cause vasodilation of the arterioles supplying the working muscle, thereby decreasing local vascular resistance and significantly increasing blood flow to meet the metabolic demands of the tissue.

Explanation of other options:

Sympathetic activation (Option A): While it increases heart rate and cardiac output, it also causes vasoconstriction in non-exercising tissues. It does not directly increase local muscle blood flow.

Decreased baroreceptor activity (Option B): Baroreceptor sensitivity decreases during exercise to allow higher blood pressures, but does not directly control muscle blood flow.

Tachycardia (Option D): Increases total cardiac output but does not specifically direct more blood to the exercising muscles.
